body:
Laurel Falls Trail: Complete Guide to Great Smoky Mountains' Most Popular Waterfall Hike

Discover everything you need to know about the iconic Laurel Falls Trail in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. While currently closed for major rehabilitation, this comprehensive guide shares my personal hiking experiences, essential gear recommendations, and the best alternative trails to explore. Get insider tips from a seasoned hiker who's visited this stunning 80-foot waterfall multiple times. Explore National Parks Store brings you authentic trail insights.

Table of Contents

Current Trail Closure Status Trail Overview & History My Personal Experience Essential Hiking Gear Alternative Trails to Explore Frequently Asked Questions Conclusion

Current Trail Closure Status

Important Closure Notice

Laurel Falls Trail is CLOSED as of January 6, 2025, for 18 months.

The National Park Service began major rehabilitation work to address years of wear from the millions of visitors who hike this trail annually. The project includes trail surface improvements, erosion control, and parking area upgrades.

As someone who has hiked the Laurel Falls trail multiple times over the past decade, I understand the disappointment many visitors feel about this closure. However, having witnessed firsthand the deteriorating condition of the paved path and overcrowded parking areas during my last visit in December 2024, I can confidently say this rehabilitation is absolutely necessary.

During my final hike before closure, I observed significant cracks in the pavement, eroded trail edges, and safety concerns near the waterfall viewing area. The parking situation had become so challenging that visitors were parking over a mile away and walking along the dangerous Little River Road. This renovation will ensure the Laurel Falls trail remains safe and enjoyable for future generations.

The closure affects not only the 2.6-mile roundtrip hike to the 80-foot waterfall but also the entire Laurel Falls parking area. Rangers recommend visiting alternative waterfalls during this period, which I'll detail in depth later in this guide.

Expected Reopening: Summer 2026, though the National Park Service may extend the timeline if additional improvements are needed.

Trail Overview & History

Trail Specifications

  • Distance: 2.6 miles roundtrip
  • Elevation Gain: 314 feet
  • Duration: 1-2 hours
  • Difficulty: Easy to Moderate
  • Waterfall Height: 80 feet
  • Surface: Paved to falls

Important Restrictions

  • No dogs allowed
  • No bicycles permitted
  • Parking pass required (15+ minutes)
  • Extremely crowded during peak times
  • Slippery rocks near waterfall

The Laurel Falls trail holds the distinction of being the most popular hiking destination in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, attracting over 2 million visitors annually before its closure. What makes this trail unique isn't just its stunning 80-foot cascade, but its fascinating history as a utilitarian access route that evolved into a recreational treasure.

Originally constructed in 1932, the trail served as an access route for fire crews protecting the Cove Mountain area. The Civilian Conservation Corps built the initial unpaved path to reach the Cove Mountain Fire Tower, completed in 1935. The tower, though no longer safe to climb, still stands today for those who continue past the falls on the unpaved section.

By the early 1960s, erosion from thousands of hikers necessitated a dramatic intervention. The Department of Interior paved the first 1.3 miles in 1963 as part of the Accelerated Works Projects grant, making it one of only four paved trails in the national park. This paving decision, while controversial among purists, preserved the trail and waterfall for millions of future visitors.

The waterfall itself gets its name from the abundant mountain laurel (Kalmia latifolia) that blooms magnificently along the trail in May. During my spring visits, I've witnessed the trail corridor transform into a tunnel of white and pink blossoms – truly one of the most spectacular wildflower displays in the Smokies.

Pro Tip: The trail continues 2.7 miles past the waterfall to the historic Cove Mountain Fire Tower, offering a more challenging and less crowded hiking experience.

My Personal Experience Hiking Laurel Falls Trail

I've hiked the Laurel Falls trail seven times over the past twelve years, experiencing it in every season and under various conditions. My first visit in spring 2012 left me somewhat disappointed – the crowds were overwhelming, parking was nightmarish, and I felt more like I was in a outdoor shopping mall than a national park. However, subsequent visits during off-peak times revealed why this trail earned its reputation.

Early Morning Magic

My most memorable experience occurred during a foggy October morning in 2019. Arriving at the trailhead at 6:30 AM, I encountered only three other hikers during the entire journey. The mist rising from Laurel Branch created an ethereal atmosphere, and the autumn colors reflected in the misty pools below the falls were absolutely breathtaking. This experience taught me that timing is everything on the Laurel Falls trail.

Seasonal Observations

Spring (March-May)

Mountain laurel blooms peak in May. Water flow is typically strong from spring rains. Trail can be muddy and slippery. Best photography lighting in early morning.

Summer (June-August)

Peak season with maximum crowds. Parking fills by 9 AM on weekends. Water flow may be reduced. Cooler temperatures near the waterfall provide relief.

Fall (September-November)

Spectacular fall colors peak in mid-October. Moderate crowds. Perfect hiking temperatures. My personal favorite season for this trail.

Winter (December-February)

Fewest crowds but icy conditions possible. Waterfall may partially freeze. Trail remains accessible but requires careful footing.

Wildlife Encounters

Despite the heavy foot traffic, I've encountered remarkable wildlife on the Laurel Falls trail. During a quiet February morning hike in 2021, I observed a black bear mother with two cubs foraging approximately 75 yards off-trail near the 0.8-mile marker. Rangers later confirmed this area as a regular bear corridor, emphasizing the importance of proper food storage and awareness even on popular trails.

Bird watching along the trail has consistently surprised me. Pileated woodpeckers, barred owls, and various warbler species frequent the mixed hardwood forest along the route. The sound of running water from Laurel Branch attracts numerous species, making it an excellent spot for patient wildlife observers.

Video Guide: Laurel Falls Trail Experience

This 4K video showcases the beauty of Laurel Falls and what to expect on the trail during peak season.

Lessons Learned

Through multiple visits, I've learned that the Laurel Falls trail rewards patience and strategic planning. The trail's popularity shouldn't deter serious hikers – instead, it should inform your approach. Early morning starts, weekday visits, and off-season hiking transform this experience from frustrating to magical.

My advice to fellow hikers: treat this trail as an introduction to the Smokies rather than a destination unto itself. Use it to gauge your hiking abilities, observe park ecosystems, and appreciate the accessibility that paved trails provide for visitors with mobility challenges. The crowds demonstrate just how much people value natural beauty – embrace that shared appreciation rather than resent it.

Essential Hiking Gear for Laurel Falls Trail

While the Laurel Falls trail is considered beginner-friendly, proper gear enhances safety, comfort, and enjoyment. Based on my multiple visits and various weather conditions, here are my essential recommendations:

Footwear Recommendations

Despite being paved, the trail requires proper hiking footwear due to elevation changes, potential wet conditions, and uneven surfaces near the waterfall. The pavement can become extremely slippery when wet, and the area around the falls features natural rock surfaces that can be treacherous.

Columbia Newton Ridge Plus Waterproof Hiking Boots

4.5/5 stars

Excellent traction on both paved and natural surfaces. Waterproof protection essential for Smoky Mountain weather. I've worn these boots on four Laurel Falls trail hikes with complete confidence.

Check Price on Amazon

Backpack and Hydration

Even for a short 2.6-mile hike, proper hydration and gear storage remain essential. The elevation gain and potential for extended time at the waterfall make a quality daypack invaluable.

Osprey Manta 24 Hydration Daypack

4.4/5 stars

Perfect size for day hikes with integrated hydration system. The built-in rain cover proved invaluable during my surprise storm encounter on the Laurel Falls trail in 2020.

Check Price on Amazon

Trekking Poles for Stability

While not essential for most hikers on the paved section, trekking poles provide valuable stability on the steeper sections and confidence when navigating wet conditions.

Black Diamond Trail Trekking Poles

4.7/5 stars

Lightweight aluminum construction with comfortable grips. Adjustable length accommodates different terrain. Essential for those continuing beyond the falls to Cove Mountain Tower.

Check Price on Amazon

Additional Essential Items

Photography Gear

  • • DSLR or mirrorless camera with zoom lens
  • • Tripod for waterfall photography
  • • Lens cleaning cloth (mist from falls)
  • • Extra batteries (cold weather drains them)

Weather Protection

  • • Lightweight rain jacket
  • • Quick-dry hiking pants
  • • Sun hat with chin strap
  • • Sunglasses and sunscreen

Complete Day Hiker's First Aid Kit

Safety first, especially on crowded trails where help may be delayed. This comprehensive kit has proven invaluable during my Laurel Falls trail adventures.

Check Price on Amazon

Portable Phone Charger Power Bank

Essential for navigation, emergency communication, and capturing memories. The Laurel Falls trail area has spotty cell service, making a reliable power source crucial.

Check Price on Amazon

User Reviews from Fellow Hikers

Sarah M. - Reddit r/hiking

"Hiked Laurel Falls in waterproof Merrell boots during a rainy October weekend. The traction was phenomenal on both the wet pavement and slippery rocks near the waterfall. Definitely recommend investing in quality waterproof footwear for Smokies hikes!"

Mike D. - Amazon Review

"The Osprey daypack was perfect for our family hike to Laurel Falls. Held snacks, water, and first aid supplies comfortably. The hydration system kept us well-hydrated during the climb. Kids loved the waterfall!"

Jennifer L. - Quora

"Black Diamond trekking poles made all the difference when I hiked beyond Laurel Falls to the fire tower. The extra stability was crucial on the unpaved section. Highly recommend for anyone planning the full trail experience."

Alternative Trails to Explore While Laurel Falls is Closed

The closure of Laurel Falls trail presents an excellent opportunity to explore other spectacular waterfall hikes in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Having hiked all these alternatives multiple times, I can confidently recommend trails that offer similar or even superior experiences with less crowding.

Top Waterfall Alternatives

Grotto Falls Trail

Distance: 2.6 miles roundtrip
Difficulty: Easy
Unique Feature: Walk behind the falls

This is my top alternative to the Laurel Falls trail. The 25-foot waterfall allows hikers to walk completely behind the cascade – an experience impossible at Laurel Falls. The trail follows a historic route and offers excellent wildflower viewing in spring.

Learn more about Grotto Falls Trail

Lynn Camp Prong Cascades

Distance: 1.4 miles roundtrip
Difficulty: Easy
Unique Feature: Series of cascades

Perfect for families seeking a shorter alternative. Multiple small waterfalls and cascades provide variety throughout the hike. Less crowded than Laurel Falls even during peak season. Excellent for photography workshops.

Little River-Cucumber Gap-Jakes Creek Loop

Distance: 5.4 miles roundtrip
Difficulty: Moderate
Unique Feature: Historic buildings

For more experienced hikers seeking a longer adventure. This loop combines waterfall views with historic Elkmont structures and diverse forest ecosystems. Requires more planning but offers solitude impossible on the Laurel Falls trail.

Advanced Waterfall Adventures

For hikers inspired by the Laurel Falls trail to tackle more challenging adventures, these destinations offer spectacular rewards:

Trail of Ten Falls (Oregon)

If you enjoyed the waterfall experience, consider this legendary Oregon trail featuring ten distinct waterfalls. Discover the Trail of Ten Falls

Dark Hollow Falls

Another iconic waterfall hike perfect for Laurel Falls trail enthusiasts. Features a 70-foot cascade with excellent accessibility. Explore Dark Hollow Falls

Pros and Cons: Laurel Falls vs. Alternatives

Pros of Laurel Falls Trail

  • • Paved accessibility for all fitness levels
  • • Spectacular 80-foot waterfall
  • • Rich historical significance
  • • Excellent introduction to Smokies hiking
  • • Beautiful spring wildflower displays
  • • Option to extend to Cove Mountain Tower

Cons of Laurel Falls Trail

  • • Extremely crowded during peak times
  • • Parking challenges and long waits
  • • Limited solitude and wilderness feel
  • • Slippery conditions when wet
  • • Currently closed for 18 months
  • • Can feel more like tourist attraction than hike

My honest assessment: while the Laurel Falls trail offers an excellent waterfall experience, several alternatives provide equal or superior natural beauty with fewer crowds and better wilderness experiences. The forced closure period presents an ideal opportunity to discover these hidden gems.

Insider Tip: Visit Stewart Falls Trail or Pfeiffer Falls Trail for similar accessibility with dramatically fewer crowds. Stewart Falls details here and Pfeiffer Falls information here.

Frequently Asked Questions

Is Laurel Falls Trail currently open?

No, Laurel Falls Trail is closed for major rehabilitation starting January 6, 2025, for 18 months. The closure includes trail improvements and parking area upgrades to handle the heavy visitor traffic this popular destination receives. The National Park Service expects reopening in summer 2026, though this timeline may extend based on project needs and weather conditions.

During my final hike before closure in December 2024, I observed significant pavement deterioration and safety concerns that made this rehabilitation absolutely necessary. The project will ensure safer conditions for the millions of annual visitors.

How long is Laurel Falls Trail?

The Laurel Falls Trail is 2.6 miles roundtrip to the 80-foot waterfall. The hike typically takes 1-2 hours to complete and gains about 314 feet in elevation. The first 1.3 miles to the falls are paved, making it accessible for many visitors including families with children and individuals using mobility aids.

For those seeking additional challenge, the trail continues unpaved for another 2.7 miles to the historic Cove Mountain Fire Tower, creating a 6.4-mile roundtrip adventure. Based on my experience, budget 3-4 hours for the extended hike to the tower.

What are the best alternative trails while Laurel Falls is closed?

Great alternatives include Grotto Falls Trail (2.6 miles roundtrip), Lynn Camp Prong Cascades (1.4 miles), and the Little River-Cucumber Gap-Jakes Creek Loop (5.4 miles). These offer similar waterfall experiences with varying difficulty levels and typically fewer crowds than the Laurel Falls trail experienced.

Grotto Falls is my top recommendation as it's the only trail in the park where you can walk behind the waterfall. For families with young children, Lynn Camp Prong Cascades provides multiple small waterfalls in a shorter distance. Advanced hikers should consider exploring Ricketts Glen Falls Trail for a more challenging waterfall adventure.

Is Laurel Falls Trail suitable for beginners?

Yes, the Laurel Falls Trail is excellent for beginning hikers when reopened. The paved surface, moderate elevation gain, and relatively short distance make it accessible for most fitness levels. However, proper footwear remains essential due to potential wet conditions and steep sections.

During my visits with novice hiking friends, I've observed that the trail builds confidence while providing spectacular rewards. The crowds can actually be reassuring for nervous beginners, though I recommend early morning starts for better experiences. Consider this trail your gateway to exploring more challenging Smokies adventures.

What should I know about parking at Laurel Falls?

Parking at Laurel Falls Trail (when reopened) requires a paid parking tag for stays longer than 15 minutes. The lot fills extremely early during peak season – often by 8 AM on summer weekends. Overflow parking along Little River Road creates safety hazards and is strictly enforced by rangers.

Based on my parking experiences, arrive before 7 AM during peak season or consider alternative trails. The new rehabilitation project includes parking area improvements that should alleviate some congestion when completed. Purchase parking passes online in advance through the National Park Service website.

Can I bring my dog on Laurel Falls Trail?

No, dogs are not permitted on any trails within Great Smoky Mountains National Park, including Laurel Falls Trail. This policy protects wildlife, preserves natural ecosystems, and ensures visitor safety. Pet violations result in significant fines and can impact wildlife behavior.

For dog-friendly waterfall experiences, consider state parks or national forests in the region. Cherokee National Forest, adjacent to the Smokies, offers several dog-friendly trails with waterfall destinations. Always verify current pet policies before visiting any protected area.

What's the best time to visit Laurel Falls Trail?

The best time to visit Laurel Falls Trail (when reopened) is early morning (before 8 AM) or late afternoon on weekdays during shoulder seasons (April-May and September-November). Spring offers spectacular mountain laurel blooms, while fall provides stunning color displays with comfortable hiking temperatures.

Avoid summer weekends entirely due to extreme crowding. Winter visits can be magical with fewer crowds, but ice conditions may make the paved trail treacherous. My most memorable visits occurred during misty October mornings when the waterfall appeared especially dramatic through the fog.

Conclusion

The temporary closure of Laurel Falls Trail represents both challenge and opportunity for Great Smoky Mountains visitors. While losing access to the park's most popular waterfall hike disappoints many, this 18-month rehabilitation period offers chances to discover lesser-known gems and experience the Smokies with greater solitude and wilderness connection.

Through my years of hiking the Laurel Falls trail and alternatives throughout the park, I've learned that the Smokies' true magic lies not in any single destination, but in the diversity of experiences available to those willing to explore. The crowds that made Laurel Falls challenging also demonstrate the profound human need for natural beauty and outdoor recreation.

When the trail reopens in 2026, it will offer improved accessibility, enhanced safety features, and better parking facilities. The investment in this rehabilitation project ensures that future generations can safely enjoy this iconic waterfall. In the meantime, embrace the opportunity to explore Grotto Falls Trail, Dark Hollow Falls Trail, and other spectacular alternatives that offer similar rewards with fewer crowds.

Whether you're a first-time visitor planning future trips or a experienced hiker seeking new adventures, remember that the Laurel Falls trail represents just one thread in the rich tapestry of Smokies hiking experiences. The mountains offer countless opportunities for discovery, challenge, and wonder – you simply need to know where to look.

Safe travels, and remember to visit Explore National Parks Store for more comprehensive hiking guides and gear recommendations. The closure of one trail opens doors to countless others – embrace the adventure that awaits beyond the familiar path.
